sectionCopy.name: Barriers
sectionCopy.value: Ecuador faces barriers to the deployment of more renewable generation due to key characteristics of its power market. A combination of very low electricity tariffs, fossil fuel subsidies for electricity generation and low power demand growth produces a challenging environment for project developers. The country is able to meet peak power demand via its hydro capacity alone.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy investment
sectionCopy.value: Investment in clean energy in Ecuador has been limited. From 2011 to 2017, the total invested amounted was only $489 million, mainly in small hydro assets. In 2018, the country did not receive any investment. In 2019, it attracted $100 million for wind projects. Development banks Inter-American Investment Corporation and Corporaci√≥n Andina de Fomento (CAF) are the biggest lead arrangers in the country, mainly investing in small hydro.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy policy
sectionCopy.value: Ecuador does not have a clear target for renewables, despite claiming an interest to raise clean generation by 2025. The country did not achieve its 90% hydro target to be met by 2017, even with the addition of 2GW of hydro capacity in 2016. The government gives priority of dispatch for biomass, geothermal, small hydro, solar, tidal and wind projects. Renewable energy developers may apply for import tax exemption on clean energy equipment and a five-year waiver on income tax. Furthermore, on November 2018 the government introduced a net metering system, applicable for residential users with an installed capacity up to 300 kW of PV and industrial users with up to 500 kW. Despite that, deployment of wind and solar assets has been minimal. In 2019, the country launched a renewable auction for a 110MW wind portfolio and a solar PV project of 200MW. The Ministry of Energy received offers from Solarpack, Cobra Zero-E, Neoen and Total and intended to award concessions by year-end 2020.  The government also launched a tender for solar-plus-storage in the Galapagos Islands, aiming to reduce reliance on diesel generation. Ecuador was one of the few countries in Latin America to offer a feed-in-tariff for renewables, but it is currently not in force.

sectionCopy.name: Doing business
sectionCopy.value: On October 13, 2015, Ecuador submitted its unconditional Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC) to the United Nations, committing to cut greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the energy sector by 20.4%-25% below the business as usual (BAU) scenario by 2025. Ecuador also committed to a further reduction of GHG emissions in the energy sector to a level between 37.5% and 45.8% below the BAU scenario by 2025. This additional reduction is conditioned upon availability of resources and international support.

sectionCopy.name: Power market
sectionCopy.value: In Ecuador, the Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy (MEER) oversees renewable energy policy and planning. In 2015, the Act Establishing the Public Electric Power Service (LOSPEE) was published, overseeing the power sector in Ecuador. Under this law, the National Electricity Board (CONELEC) becomes the Agency for Regulation and Control of Electricity (ARCONEL). While generation is open to private players in Ecuador, transmission is under the responsibility of state-owned utility Corporaci√≥n El√©ctrica del Ecuador (CELEC EP Transelectric). Distribution is divided between 11 majority-public companies, in which MEER is the majority shareholder. In 2019, Ecuador had a total of 8.6GW of installed capacity, with hydro representing 51% and thermal power accounting for 39% of its mix. Clean energy, encompassing small hydro, biomass, wind and solar plants, represents 9% of total capacity.

sectionCopy.name: Power prices and LCOEs
sectionCopy.value: Commercial and residential power prices slightly increased in 2019 compared to 2018, the tariffs were $104.40/MWh for commercial and $102.80/MWh for residential, compared to $103.90/MWh (commercial) and $101.50/MWh (residential) in 2018. Industrial tariffs decreased $0.20/MWh, from $80.10 in 2018 to $79.90/MWh.
